title: Problem Statement
content: Erdős Problem #996 asks: For lacunary sequences and L² functions, if the Fourier error decays like 1/(log log log n)^C, does the strong law of large numbers hold? This connects harmonic analysis, probability, and ergodic theory.

title: Mathlib Imports
content: We import measure theory (for integration and almost-everywhere statements), Fourier analysis on the circle, logarithm functions, and filter theory for limits. These form the mathematical foundation.

title: Lacunary Sequences
content: A sequence n₁ < n₂ < ... is **lacunary** if n(k+1)/n(k) ≥ λ for some λ > 1. This means the gaps grow exponentially. Example: 2^k has gaps doubling each time.

title: Powers of 2 are Lacunary
content: The sequence 1, 2, 4, 8, 16, ... (powers of 2) is lacunary with λ = 2. Each term is exactly twice the previous, so the ratio is constant at 2.

title: Powers of 3 are Lacunary
content: Similarly, 1, 3, 9, 27, ... (powers of 3) is lacunary with λ = 3. Any geometric sequence a^k with a ≥ 2 is lacunary.

title: Lacunary Implies Increasing
content: Any lacunary sequence is strictly increasing. Since n(k+1)/n(k) > 1, we have n(k+1) > n(k) for all k.

title: Fourier Partial Sums
content: The Nth Fourier partial sum fₙ(x) uses frequencies from -N to N. It's the best L² approximation of f using trigonometric polynomials of degree N.

title: Fourier Error
content: The L² error ‖f - fₙ‖₂ measures how well the partial sum approximates f. Smoother functions have faster-decaying error. This decay rate is central to Problem #996.

title: Parseval's Identity
content: Parseval's identity: the L² norm of f equals the sum of squared Fourier coefficients. This connects the function space norm to the frequency domain.

title: Fractional Part
content: The fractional part {x} = x - ⌊x⌋ gives the remainder when x is divided by 1. This maps ℝ to [0,1), which is where we evaluate the periodic function f.

title: Ergodic Average
content: The ergodic average (1/N) Σₖ<N f({α·nₖ}) samples f along the orbit of α under the lacunary sequence. This is a 'time average' along the dynamical trajectory.

title: Space Average
content: The space average ∫₀¹ f(x)dx is the integral of f over [0,1]. The strong law says the ergodic average converges to this for almost every starting point α.

title: Strong Law Holds
content: The strong law holds for (f, n, α) if the ergodic average converges to the space average as N → ∞. This is the pointwise ergodic theorem for the specific α.

title: Strong Law Almost Everywhere
content: The strong law holds almost everywhere if it holds for almost every α ∈ [0,1]. This uses measure theory: the set of 'bad' α has measure zero.

title: Raikov's Theorem
content: **Raikov**: For geometric sequences nₖ = aᵏ (a ≥ 2), the strong law holds for ALL f ∈ L² without any Fourier decay condition. Geometric sequences are 'maximally lacunary'.

title: Kac-Salem-Zygmund (1948)
content: **KSZ 1948**: If Fourier error decays like 1/(log n)^c for c > 1, the strong law holds for any lacunary sequence. First general result for non-geometric lacunary sequences.

title: Erdős (1949)
content: **Erdős 1949**: Improved to 1/(log log n)^c for c > 1. This replaces log with log log—a significant weakening of the required decay condition.

title: Matsuyama (1966)
content: **Matsuyama 1966**: Further improved the exponent from c > 1 to c > 1/2 for log log decay. This is the current best known result. Halving the exponent is a major improvement.

title: Problem #996 Statement
content: **THE OPEN QUESTION**: Is there a constant C such that 1/(log log log n)^C decay suffices? This asks if we can add another 'log' to the hierarchy.

title: Open Status
content: The problem remains OPEN. We don't know if log log log decay (with any exponent) is sufficient for the strong law.

title: Floor Power Question
content: Related question: Does the strong law hold for nₖ = ⌊aᵏ⌋ with real a > 1? This is between geometric (a integer) and general lacunary sequences.

title: Bounded Function Question
content: Another open question: Does the strong law hold for ALL bounded functions f and lacunary sequences n, without any Fourier decay condition?

title: Decay Condition Structure
content: We formalize the hierarchy of decay conditions: log, log log, log log log. Each is weaker than the previous, and we track which are known to suffice.

title: Log Decay
content: The log decay condition: error ≤ 1/(log n)^c for c > 1. This was the original KSZ (1948) requirement.

title: Log Log Decay
content: The log log decay condition: error ≤ 1/(log log n)^c. Erdős (1949) showed c > 1 suffices; Matsuyama (1966) improved to c > 1/2.

title: Log Log Log Decay
content: The log log log decay condition: error ≤ 1/(log log log n)^c. UNKNOWN whether any exponent c suffices. This is Problem #996.

title: Quasi-Independence
content: Lacunary sequences have 'quasi-independence': the fractional parts {α·nₖ} behave almost like independent random variables. This is why probabilistic tools apply.

title: Consecutive Not Lacunary
content: The consecutive integers n(k) = k+1 are NOT lacunary: (k+2)/(k+1) → 1, not ≥ λ > 1. The strong law can fail for such sequences.

title: The Known Gap
content: We KNOW log log decay with c > 1/2 suffices (Matsuyama). We DON'T KNOW if log log log decay ever suffices. The gap is one iterated logarithm.

title: Weyl Equidistribution
content: Weyl's theorem: {αn} is equidistributed mod 1 for irrational α. This is a precursor—lacunary sequences give a 'sparse' version with similar equidistribution.

title: Summary Theorem
content: **SUMMARY**: We know log log decay with c > 1/2 works (Matsuyama). The question of whether log log log decay suffices remains OPEN. The formalization captures both the known results and the open problem.
